instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message:
I have this board that was liquid damaged around by the SMC <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> mostly. I have UC'd the board and replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> as well as some resistors that were damaged by the SMC.
I am now getting 1.57v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. I checked for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and it is showing 0v and not even a pulse when the machine turns on.

Here are some other measurements I got.

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> - 0.06v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 0.02v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message:
Start checking resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
Post voltages for <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message: Yeah we need more things before PCH power. What is your exact voltage on PPBUS? <SIGNAL>VRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message:
Sorry I forgot to mention those voltages but I get 8.58v on ppbus and 3.4v on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>. I will give you the voltage for <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> in a couple of hours.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.45v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message: Ok so something is wrong near the TPS as you need <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. Post voltages for the pins 2informaticos asked for.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message:
Sorry I was on my phone and didn't see 2informaticos' post. I did replace the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> chip but here are some of the measurements.
Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is around 50kohms.
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
Pin 12 - 3.45v
Pin 13 - 2.00v
Pin 21 - 3.4v
Pin 22 - 3.3v
Pin 23 - 8.57v
Pin 29 - 1.58v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message:
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR>; still the same?
Also remove L4820; to discard trackpad connector.
Finally remove <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> AND <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>; you can cut off trace from pin 12/<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> instead.
Do NOT power up the board without <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, when <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR> is still soldered!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message: So after I remove <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> I should power on the board and see if <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> goes to 5v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message:
Better to remve them one by one.
Be carefull about <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message: Yeah you can try with those caps removed. Just don't power it on with <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> off the board. Or <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> for that matter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.57v no PCH power
threads.message:
Okay I figured out that <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> was issue had some solder connecting it to the probe point in front of it. I figured they were connected so I didn't bother separating the solder but it is all fixed now.

Thanks guys!
